properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of freezing rain continues early this morning. Freezing rain has developed and is expected to be mixed with ice pellets at times. Precipitation is expected to transition back to snow in the next several hours. This period of freezing rain could bring measurable ice accretion up to 5 mm over some areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T13:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T06:24:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1957946512.2021
Area: Watford - Pinery Park - Eastern Lambton County, Sarnia - Petrolia - Western Lambton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to diminish on Saturday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-01-02T19:59:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2021-01-02T03:28:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3446437171.2021
Area: Portneuf area, Valcartier - Stoneham area, Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, Bellechasse area, Lévis area, Saint-Lambert area, Lotbinière area, Lac-Etchemin area, Sainte-Marie-de-Beauce area, Saint-Georges-de-Beauce area, Montmagny - Saint-Jean-Port-Joli area, Saint-Fabien - Saint-Pamphile area

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow will develop beginning overnight tonight. Total snowfall amounts of 15 cm are expected by end of day on Saturday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible early this morning. Snow mixed with patchy freezing rain or ice pellets continues early this morning. Some ice accretion due to freezing rain is possible. Precipitation will transition back to snow before sunrise with additional snowfall amounts near 5 cm possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain is expected early this morning. Freezing rain and ice pellets have developed as temperatures are near or just below the freezing mark. Freezing rain and ice pellets are expected to continue early this morning before changing to snow near sunrise and then ending later this morning. An ice accretion near 2 mm is possible, particularly away from Lake Ontario. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Locations: Southern New Brunswick Time span: this morning until this evening. Remarks: Generally 15 to 25 cm of snow is expected with the possibility of locally higher amounts. Additionally, strong east to northeast winds gusting to 60 km/h may at times reduce visibility in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continues early this morning for areas away from Lake Ontario. Freezing rain and ice pellets continue for areas roughly north of Highway 401. For areas south of Highway 401, including cities like Mississauga, rain continues with a much lower chance of any freezing rain. Ice accretion amounts of 2 to 4 mm are possible. Precipitation will transition back to snow before sunrise, with additional snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 cm possible. Snow will come to an end later this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Significant amounts of snow will fall over the higher elevations of Highway 93, such as Bow Summit and Sunwapta Pass, this weekend. The heaviest snow will fall on Saturday night and end by Sunday evening. Total accumulations will be from 30 to 50 cm. Gusty westerly winds in some areas may also cause near zero visibility in blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T21:00:50-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible tonight, along with snow. Snow may become mixed with ice pellets or periods of freezing rain or freezing drizzle late this evening and overnight. Some ice accretion is possible. Moderate to heavy snow will redevelop overnight with 5 to 10 cm of snowfall accumulation expected by the time the snow comes to an end early Saturday morning. At this point, the freezing rain is expected to be brief and patchy. However, freezing rain warnings may be needed if a longer lasting period of freezing rain is expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 7 to 14 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 70 km/h (possibly higher along parts of the coast). Locations; Burin Peninsula and southern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Visibilities deteriorating overnight, then improving Sunday morning on the Burin Peninsula and near noon Sunday elsewhere. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-03T00:40:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T08:40:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3860749643.2021

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Moderate to heavy snow is expected early this morning as a low pressure system moves off to the east. Conditions are expected to improve late this morning as snow is expected to end near mid morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Another moist Pacific front will move across Vancouver Island on Saturday. Rainfall amounts of near 50 mm are expected between Qualicum Beach and Fanny Bay. The rain will end by Saturday evening as the front moves out of the region. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. This Winter Weather Travel Advisory has been upgraded from a Special Weather Statement that was previously in effect. Moderate to heavy snow will continue this morning as a low pressure system moves off to the east. A snowfall accumulation of 10 to 15 cm is possible early this morning. This snowfall may result in difficult winter driving conditions as roads can become snow covered and icy. Conditions are expected to improve late this morning as snow is expected to end near mid morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 25 to 30 cm is expected. Locations: Nova Scotia Time span: This morning until overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow will develop this morning in the west and spread to the rest of the province by this afternoon. Generally 15 to 25 cm of snow is expected however 30 cm or more is possible over northern and eastern areas of the province. Furthermore, strong east to northeast winds gusting to 60 to 80 km/h may significantly reduce visibility in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Road closures are possible. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-03T00:53:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-02T08:53:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0416871368.2021

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues this morning with a total of 15 cm expected by the time it ends. Hazards: 15 cm total of snow Heavy snowfall rates up to 4 cm per hour at times Timing: Snow continues through late this morning. The heaviest snow of the event is expected during this time. Impacts: Poor visibility in heavy snowfall Poor road conditions due to quickly accumulating snow Discussion: Regional weather RADAR shows snow continuing in eastern Ontario. Periods of heavy snow are expected during the next several hours before the snow eases and clears late this morning. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are expected. Ottawa Airport has reported 4 cm of snow as of 4 a.m. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-02T18:59:47-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of freezing rain continues early this morning. Freezing rain will transition back to snow in the next few hours with additional snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 cm possible. This prolonged period of freezing rain is expected to bring up to 5 mm of ice accretion to many areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm expected. Time span: today and tonight. Remarks: Snow will start this morning over western areas of the province and reach Cape Breton by this afternoon. The snow will change to rain near noon in the west and then change back to a period of snow this evening before ending. Over western Cape Breton the snow will taper off to a few flurries overnight. Total snowfall accumulation of 10 to 15 cm is expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
